'Records of the Grand Historian' is still considered a treasure of Chinese historiography and literature, exerting a profound influence on later generations.

Chinese tea culture has a profound historical background and rich cultural connotations, forming an integral part of Chinese civilization. It is manifested not only in the production and consumption of tea but also encompasses tea art, tea ceremony, tea etiquette, tea morality, and tea philosophy.

Tea, originating in ancient China, has a history of several thousand years. The earliest written records appear in the 'Shennong Bencao Jing,' describing the medicinal value of tea. Legend has it that Shennong tasted hundreds of herbs and discovered the detoxifying effect of tea leaves. Chinese tea culture flourished during the Tang Dynasty, with Lu Yu's 'The Classic of Tea' being the world's earliest monograph on tea, systematically summarizing tea planting, processing, brewing, and art of drinking.

The tea ceremony emphasizes a spiritual and aesthetic enjoyment, embodying the concepts of nature, simplicity, harmony, and tranquility. It is not just a skill of brewing and drinking tea but also a manifestation of culture, emphasizing the ambiance and interaction with people during tea drinking.

Different regions in China have developed their unique tea cultures. For example, there are the Minnan tea ceremony in Fujian, Gongfu tea in Guangdong, and tea house culture in Sichuan and Jiangsu. Tea art performance is an artistic presentation within tea culture, showcasing the art of brewing through graceful movements, brewing techniques, and the selection of utensils.

Chinese tea culture has also influenced the world. For example, Japanese tea ceremony was influenced by Chinese tea culture during the Tang Dynasty. Moreover, with the development of Chinese tea trade, Chinese tea has spread to various parts of the world, becoming one of the globally popular beverages.

In modern times, Chinese tea culture is not only preserved in tradition but also closely connected with modern life, becoming a part of people's daily interactions and leisure activities. Additionally, various tea culture festivals, exhibitions, and exchange activities are widely held nationwide and globally, attracting numerous tea enthusiasts and cultural scholars.

Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM), deeply rooted in ancient China, is a comprehensive medical system deeply integrated with Chinese philosophy, culture, and science. Its theoretical foundation includes Taoist Yin-Yang and Five Elements theory, Confucian benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and Buddhist karma, forming a unique medical theoretical system. TCM views the human body as a holistic entity, emphasizing the harmony between humans and nature, and conducts disease prevention, diagnosis, and treatment through dialectical analysis.

TCM employs various treatment methods, including herbal medicine, acupuncture, cupping, scraping, dietary therapy, Tai Chi, Qigong, and other non-pharmacological therapies. Chinese herbal medicine, primarily consisting of natural medicinal substances such as plants, animals, and minerals, is one of the most widely used methods in TCM. Acupuncture involves stimulating specific acupoints on the body surface with needles to adjust the body's Qi and blood.

TCM believes that the state of health is determined by the interaction and regulation of 'Qi,' 'blood,' 'body fluids,' 'viscera and bowels,' and 'meridians.' The occurrence of disease is due to the imbalance of these elements or the invasion of external pathogenic factors. In treatment, TCM diagnoses diseases through observation, listening, questioning, and pulse-taking, and formulates treatment plans accordingly.

With a history of thousands of years, TCM is still widely practiced in China and complements Western medicine in modern society. Although the efficacy and mechanism of TCM are sometimes disputed in the modern medical community, its dissemination and practice worldwide demonstrate that TCM, as a medical modality, has made positive contributions to promoting human health. With the in-depth research and technological advancements in TCM, it is gradually being accepted and recognized by more people worldwide.

Leslie Cheung, born Leslie Cheung Kwok-wing on September 12, 1956, in Hong Kong, is an internationally acclaimed singer, actor, and musician. Renowned for his versatility and profound artistic expression, he has left an indelible mark on the Asian entertainment industry.

Leslie Cheung rose to prominence in the early 1980s Hong Kong pop music scene, known for his lyrical style and extravagant stage performances. His unique vocal style allowed him to passionately interpret songs, conveying deep emotions to listeners. During the 1980s to 1990s, Leslie Cheung achieved tremendous success in the Chinese music industry with hit songs like 'Wind Continues to Blow,' 'Monica,' and 'When Love Becomes a Memory,' earning him the title of 'God of Songs.'

In the realm of cinema, Leslie Cheung also excelled, being a prominent figure in the Hong Kong New Wave cinema. His performances in films directed by Wong Kar-wai such as 'Ashes of Time,' 'In the Mood for Love,' and 'Happy Together' were highly praised, showcasing his strong dramatic prowess and profound understanding of characters. Particularly, his portrayal of Cheng Dieyi in 'Farewell My Concubine' elevated his acting to new heights, becoming an iconic figure in his career.

Leslie Cheung's artistic career extends beyond music and film; he also had remarkable performances in stage plays and musicals. His contributions to the stage affirmed him as a versatile artist.

Unfortunately, on April 1, 2003, Leslie Cheung tragically committed suicide by jumping from the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Hong Kong at the age of 46. His passing shocked and deeply saddened his fans and the entire Chinese entertainment industry. Leslie Cheung's death brought attention to depression and mental health issues in society. His music and film works have left behind a rich cultural heritage, profoundly influencing artists in subsequent generations. Even after his death, his fans and admirers continue to commemorate him in various ways, ensuring the preservation of his artistic spirit.

Oracle Bone Script is a form of ancient Chinese writing mainly found from the late Shang Dynasty to the early Western Zhou Dynasty, dating back over 3600 years. These characters were inscribed on animal bones or tortoise shells, hence the name 'Oracle Bone Script.' The discovery of Oracle Bone Script is considered a significant milestone in Chinese paleography, with immeasurable value for studying ancient Chinese language, culture, and social life.

Oracle Bone Script was used in divination activities, where the diviners of the Shang Dynasty would inscribe questions on tortoise shells or animal bones, such as inquiries about weather, agriculture, diseases, warfare, and royal affairs. They would then observe the cracks that appeared when heating these bones, interpreting the divine message. These records not only included the questions and outcomes of divinations but also sometimes recorded contemporary events.

In 1899, Wang Yirong first discovered and identified Oracle Bone Script. Subsequently, large quantities of artifacts containing Oracle Bone Script were excavated from the Yinxu site in Anyang, Henan Province, known as the 'Yinxu Inscriptions.' Through the study of Oracle Bone Script, scholars have gained a deeper understanding of the history of the Shang Dynasty.

Oracle Bone Script occupies a foundational position in the development of Chinese writing. It is not only one of the early forms of Chinese characters but also directly influenced the formation of later Chinese characters. The discovery of Oracle Bone Script is of significant importance for understanding the development of early Chinese civilization, providing a clear clue to the origins of modern Chinese characters. The field of study for these ancient scripts, known as oracle bone studies, has become an important branch of Chinese archaeology and ancient script research.

Wu Zetian (624–705), originally named Wu Mei, later changed to Wu Zhao, was the only female emperor in Chinese history. Her reign marked the peak and transformation of the Tang Dynasty. Initially entering the court as a concubine of Emperor Taizong of Tang, Li Shimin, Wu Zetian later became the empress of Emperor Gaozong of Tang. Wu Zetian showcased her intelligence and political acumen, gradually involving herself in politics during Emperor Gaozong's illness and eventually becoming the empress dowager, effectively holding imperial power.

During the brief reigns of her sons Emperor Zhongzong of Tang, Li Xian, and Emperor Ruizong of Tang, Li Dan, Wu Zetian, as empress dowager, wielded political control and eventually declared herself emperor in 690, establishing the Zhou Dynasty and interrupting the history of the Tang Dynasty. Her regime, known as the 'Zhou Dynasty,' implemented a series of reforms, including weakening the power of the aristocracy, reorganizing the examination system to select officials, and promoting Buddhism. These reforms helped consolidate central authority and to some extent altered the social class structure.

During Wu Zetian's reign, Chinese society and economy experienced significant development, especially in agricultural production and handicrafts. National finances significantly improved, and her support for culture fostered prosperity in literature and the arts. However, her rule was often controversial, particularly regarding the methods she employed to consolidate power, including harsh political purges.

In 705, Wu Zetian fell seriously ill, and Emperor Zhongzong was restored to the throne, reinstating the Tang Dynasty. After Wu Zetian's death, although historical records offer mixed evaluations of her reign, her rule left an indelible mark on Chinese history. Remembered as a controversial but highly capable ruler, her political acumen and strategies demonstrated remarkable achievements as a woman in a male-dominated society.

The Nanjing Massacre, also known as the Nanjing Massacre Incident or the Rape of Nanjing, refers to the large-scale massacre and atrocities committed by the Imperial Japanese Army against civilians and Chinese soldiers in the city of Nanjing after its occupation on December 13, 1937, until the end of January 1938. This horrific tragedy is one of the most brutal war crimes of the Second Sino-Japanese War and one of the most serious war crimes in modern warfare history.

During this six-week period, according to historians and eyewitness accounts, the Japanese army not only indiscriminately slaughtered a large number of innocent civilians but also perpetrated massive sexual violence against women, including rape, sexual abuse, and the killing of women. Additionally, the Japanese army engaged in looting, arson, and other atrocities. Estimates of the death toll vary from hundreds of thousands to around three hundred thousand, with around 300,000 being the widely accepted figure.

This event has long been a sensitive topic in Sino-Japanese relations, with ongoing controversy and politicized interpretations. While there is widespread academic consensus on the authenticity of the Nanjing Massacre, a small minority in Japan has attempted to deny or downplay its severity. To commemorate the victims, preserve historical memory, and prevent the recurrence of such tragedies, China established the Nanjing Massacre Memorial Hall in Nanjing. December 13 is designated as National Memorial Day to mourn the victims of the Nanjing Massacre.

The Nanjing Massacre holds profound significance for global history and human rights education, reminding people to remember history, cherish peace, and oppose any form of war atrocities.

Sun Yat-sen (1866–1925), originally named Sun Wen, styled himself as De-ming, later changed his name to Sun Yixian, is a prominent figure in modern Chinese history, known as the founding father of the Republic of China. Sun Yat-sen's political career aimed at overthrowing the Qing dynasty's feudal monarchy, ending over two thousand years of autocracy, and establishing the Republic of China.

Born in Zhongshan County (now Zhongshan City), Guangdong Province, into a peasant family, Sun Yat-sen received Western education in Hawaii and Hong Kong during his early years. He initially pursued a medical career but soon devoted himself to revolutionary activities aimed at overthrowing the Qing dynasty. Sun Yat-sen was one of the main leaders of the Xinhai Revolution, which led to the overthrow of the Qing dynasty in 1911 and the establishment of the Republic of China in 1912. He briefly served as the provisional president of the Republic of China but failed to maintain prolonged control due to political differences and insufficient power.

Sun Yat-sen's political ideology was encapsulated in the 'Three Principles of the People,' namely nationalism, democracy, and the people's livelihood. These principles aimed to enhance the country's independence, establish a democratic system, and improve the people's living conditions, laying the foundation for constructing a modern nation-state. Sun Yat-sen also advocated for the unity of overseas Chinese to achieve national prosperity and rejuvenation.

After Sun Yat-sen's death, the Kuomintang, under the leadership of Chiang Kai-shek, continued some of Sun Yat-sen's policies but also underwent many changes. In mainland China, Sun Yat-sen is regarded as an important revolutionary pioneer and a key figure in China's modernization process. The government of the Republic of China posthumously honored him as the 'Founding Father of the Republic of China,' and his contributions are commemorated continuously in Taiwan. Sun Yat-sen holds a high position in Chinese history and culture, revered widely in both mainland China and Taiwan.

Dream of the Red Chamber, also known as The Story of the Stone, is the pinnacle of Chinese classical literature, widely regarded as one of the peaks in the history of Chinese novels. It was written by the Qing Dynasty writer Cao Xueqin and is believed to have been completed in the mid-18th century. Originally titled 'The Story of the Stone,' it later became commonly known as 'Dream of the Red Chamber' and is considered one of the Four Great Classical Novels of Chinese literature.

The novel, set against the backdrop of the rise and fall of the four major families of Jia, Wang, Shi, and Xue, tells the tragic love story of Jia Baoyu and Lin Daiyu and his relationships with other women. The novel depicts family and romantic life in feudal society, profoundly portraying complex interpersonal relationships and the constraints of feudal ethics, while also containing philosophical and social critiques.

Dream of the Red Chamber's artistic achievement is exceptionally high, renowned for its profound philosophical content, rich imagination, exquisite artistic techniques, unique structural arrangements, and vivid language. Many of the poems in the novel are widely circulated. Coupled with finely detailed psychological descriptions and numerous lifelike character images, it has become a work of great literary value.

Moreover, this novel is not only a literary work but also a valuable resource for studying various aspects of Chinese history, culture, philosophy, and art. The study of Dream of the Red Chamber, known as 'Redology,' has developed into a specialized field encompassing extensive academic research and commentary.

The novel consists of 120 chapters, with the first 80 chapters generally believed to be authored by Cao Xueqin, while the latter 40 chapters have various versions, with the most popular being the continuation written by Gao E and Cheng Weiyuan. Despite considerable controversy over the true authorship of the latter 40 chapters, Dream of the Red Chamber as a whole remains a treasure in the cultural heritage of China.

The Mid-Autumn Festival, also known as Mooncake Festival, Autumn Festival, Zhongqiu Festival, Eighth Month Festival, Reunion Festival, Moon Worship Festival, Daughter's Festival, or Moon Chasing Festival, is a traditional festival in East Asia and Southeast Asia, mainly celebrated by the Han Chinese communities in mainland China, Taiwan, Singapore, Malaysia, Vietnam, as well as in Japan, South Korea, and North Korea. Originating in the early Tang Dynasty, it became a major festival alongside the Spring Festival by the Song Dynasty and evolved into one of China's major traditional festivals during the Ming and Qing dynasties.

The Mid-Autumn Festival falls on the fifteenth day of the eighth lunar month, typically in the middle of autumn, hence its name. On this day, the moon is believed to be at its fullest and brightest, symbolizing reunion and harvest. Therefore, it is a festival of reunion, where families strive to gather together, enjoy the joy of family bonds, and express hopes for a better future.

The Mid-Autumn Festival is celebrated with various customs such as appreciating the moon, eating mooncakes, carrying lanterns, releasing sky lanterns, solving lantern riddles, and performing dragon dances. Mooncakes and pomelos are traditional foods of the Mid-Autumn Festival. Mooncakes symbolize reunion and come in a variety of flavors and shapes, while pomelos signify auspiciousness and completeness. In some regions, people also engage in activities like admiring chrysanthemums, arranging flowers, and drinking tea to celebrate the festival.

The Mid-Autumn Festival not only serves as a traditional lunar holiday but also carries rich cultural significance and familial emotions. In modern times, it has evolved into diverse ways of celebration, expressing yearnings for a better life and longing for loved ones, whether through family reunions or gatherings with friends.

Dragon Boat Racing, also known as dragon boat regatta, is a traditional water sport originating from ancient China, held annually during the Dragon Boat Festival. It originated to commemorate the great patriotic poet Qu Yuan, who drowned himself in the Miluo River on this day in 278 BC in protest against corruption. To prevent fish and shrimp from harming his body, people paddled dragon boats and threw rice dumplings into the water to feed the creatures. This activity gradually developed into a competitive and spectacular water sport.

A dragon boat is a narrow and long watercraft, originally designed in southern China. These boats are typically decorated in the shape of a dragon, with exquisitely carved dragon heads and tails, adorned with bright colors symbolizing prayers for favorable weather and national peace. In dragon boat races, the crew members need to paddle in unison, following the drumbeat of a drummer and the commands of a steersperson, to propel the boat forward at the fastest speed.

Modern dragon boat racing has evolved into an international sport, with competitions held across Asia, the Americas, Europe, and other regions. The International Dragon Boat Federation (IDBF) and the Asian Dragon Boat Federation (ADBF) are organizations governing international dragon boat competitions. Apart from the Dragon Boat Festival, many countries and regions hold dragon boat races at different times of the year, deepening understanding of Chinese traditional culture and fostering cultural exchanges and friendships internationally.

Jay Chou, born on January 18, 1979, in New Taipei City, Taiwan Province, is a Taiwanese pop music singer, music producer, composer, lyricist, actor, director, and screenwriter, among other roles. Jay Chou has profound achievements in music, known for integrating various musical styles, especially for blending elements of Chinese traditional culture with pop music, earning international acclaim.

Since the release of his debut album 'Jay' in 2000, Jay Chou has attracted widespread attention in the Chinese music scene with his unique 'Chou-style R&B' (also known as 'New Pop R&B'). His music incorporates elements of classical, rock, pop, R&B, rap, and electronic music, creating a new landscape in Chinese pop music. Some of his songs, such as 'Common Jasmine Orange,' 'Nunchucks,' and 'Chrysanthemum Terrace,' are deeply loved by audiences, influencing the musical aesthetics of a generation.

In addition to his musical accomplishments, Jay Chou has ventured into the film industry, participating in multiple films, including 'Initial D,' 'Secret,' and 'The Green Hornet,' and directing for the first time in 'Secret,' which achieved both commercial and critical success.

Jay Chou is also a business genius. He founded his music label 'JVR Music,' owns his clothing brand, restaurant chain, and has ventured into the esports industry. His cross-disciplinary collaborations and business activities have deepened his influence among the public.

With years of development, Jay Chou has become an iconic figure in the Chinese music scene, winning numerous prestigious awards at major music award ceremonies such as the World Music Awards and the Golden Melody Awards in Taiwan, recognized as one of the leading figures in Asian pop music. His success not only promotes the internationalization of Chinese music but also contributes to the global dissemination of Asian culture.

The Giant Panda, scientifically known as Ailuropoda melanoleuca, is a rare mammal native to the mountainous regions of central China, such as Sichuan, Shaanxi, and Gansu provinces, belonging to the bear family. Renowned for its distinctive black-and-white fur, round body shape, and gentle temperament, the Giant Panda is considered a national treasure of China and a symbol of global biodiversity conservation.

Giant pandas primarily inhabit high-altitude mountainous areas and prefer solitary living. Their diet mainly consists of bamboo, which makes up about 99% of their food intake. Due to the low nutritional value of bamboo, giant pandas need to consume large quantities of it daily to meet their energy requirements, leading to extensive time spent foraging and eating.

In terms of reproduction, giant pandas are known for their low reproductive rate. Female giant pandas typically give birth once every two to three years, usually to only one cub each time, posing challenges for their survival in the wild. Additionally, giant panda cubs are fragile at birth and require close maternal care.

Since the late 20th century, due to habitat destruction and dwindling food resources, the wild population of giant pandas has faced severe threats. They were once classified as 'endangered' species by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN). However, due to continuous conservation efforts by the Chinese government and the international community, including the establishment of giant panda reserves and implementation of artificial breeding programs, the situation of giant pandas has improved and they were reclassified as 'vulnerable' species in 2016.

Apart from their ecological significance, giant pandas are also an important part of Chinese culture, often appearing in arts, media, and mascots. They serve as the symbol of the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF), representing efforts for global wildlife conservation.

Mount Tai, located in the central part of Shandong Province, China, is a famous mountain range that has been revered as one of the symbols of the Chinese nation since ancient times. It is not only the foremost among China's Five Sacred Mountains but also a UNESCO World Heritage Site for both its natural and cultural significance. The highest peak of Mount Tai is called Jade Emperor Peak, with an elevation of approximately 1545 meters.

Mount Tai holds a significant position in Chinese culture, not only for its natural landscapes but also for its profound cultural connotations and religious significance. Throughout history, many emperors and generals ascended Mount Tai to perform imperial ceremonies, offering sacrifices to heaven and earth to demonstrate the legitimacy of their rule and divine mandate. This ritual, known as Fengshan, made Mount Tai a crucial symbol of Chinese politics and religion.

The rocks of Mount Tai are mainly composed of granite, with numerous peculiar stones and diverse scenery, often shrouded in mist, giving it a majestic and mysterious atmosphere. The sunrise at Mount Tai is particularly famous, attracting numerous tourists yearning for its spectacular view. Furthermore, Mount Tai boasts numerous historical sites and cultural relics, including inscriptions, temples, and artworks, which record the rich religious and historical stories of Mount Tai.

Ecologically, Mount Tai features unique ecosystems with rich plant and animal diversity. The vegetation on the mountain exhibits distinct vertical distribution, ranging from temperate deciduous broad-leaved forests at the foot to temperate coniferous forests and subalpine plant communities towards the summit. Such diverse ecological environments make Mount Tai a treasure trove of biodiversity.

In modern times, Mount Tai has become not only a pilgrimage site for cultural and religious tourism but also a paradise for outdoor enthusiasts. Every year, millions of visitors come here for sightseeing and mountain climbing, attracted by its unique cultural status, magnificent natural scenery, and profound historical value, making it a source of pride for the Chinese nation and a treasure of the world.

Huangshan, also known as Mount Huang or Yellow Mountain, formerly known as Mount Yishan, is located in the southern part of Anhui Province, China, near the city of Huangshan. It is a renowned scenic area and UNESCO World Heritage Site, celebrated for its breathtaking natural landscapes, including peculiar pines, grotesque rocks, sea of clouds, and hot springs, known as the 'Four Wonders of Huangshan.' The pine trees on the mountain grow resiliently on steep cliffs, while the peculiar rocks take on various shapes due to weathering, forming unique formations. The sea of clouds adds an element of unpredictability to the beauty of Huangshan, while the hot springs provide a place for visitors to rest and relax.

The main peak of Huangshan, Lotus Peak, stands at an altitude of 1864 meters, offering different views from various angles. Huangshan also boasts a wealth of cultural relics, such as inscriptions left by Tang Dynasty poet Li Bai, travel notes by Ming Dynasty traveler Xu Xiake, and paintings of Huangshan by Qing Dynasty artist Huang Binhong, enriching the cultural heritage of Huangshan.

Huangshan has long been a destination sought after by literati and poets, not only serving as a prominent subject in landscape paintings but also a source of inspiration for countless poems and essays. The beauty of Huangshan holds a significant place in traditional Chinese painting and literature, exerting a profound influence.

In modern times, Huangshan attracts tourists from around the world with its well-developed tourist facilities and management. Its natural beauty and cultural depth have made it one of the most popular tourist destinations in China, offering visitors a blend of magnificent natural scenery and rich cultural heritage.

Liang Qichao (February 23, 1873 – January 19, 1929), styled Zuo Ru, pseudonym Rengong, later known as Liang Rengong, was a Chinese politician, thinker, writer, historian, educator, and publisher during the late Qing Dynasty and the Republic of China era. Liang Qichao was one of the leaders of the Reform Movement, exerting profound influence on the political, intellectual, educational, and literary realms of modern China.

Liang Qichao devoted himself to the imperial examinations in his youth but later became a reformer during the Reform Movement. He, along with Kang Youwei, advocated for the Hundred Days' Reform and gained fame for his radical proposals and eloquent propagandistic articles. After the failure of the reform, Liang Qichao went into exile overseas, continuing his revolutionary activities and playing a role in the overthrow of the Qing Dynasty. During his stay in Japan, he had a profound impact on Chinese students, discussing academic issues with them and promoting educational reforms and national modernization.

Liang Qichao not only focused on political reform but also dedicated himself to cultural and intellectual innovation. He proposed many ideas for social reform, advocating the abolition of feudal rites and promoting scientific and democratic thought. Liang Qichao firmly believed that China's rejuvenation required cultural and educational reforms to cultivate new citizens, thus his efforts in the field of education were particularly remarkable. During the late Qing and early Republican periods, Liang Qichao wrote and compiled numerous works covering history, philosophy, education, literature, and other fields. His works such as 'History of Chinese Academic Thought in the Last Three Hundred Years' and 'Collected Works of the Drinking Ice Room' had a significant impact on later generations.

Liang Qichao was also an outstanding historian, proposing the idea that 'the study of history is political science,' believing that historical research has direct implications for state governance. His historical perspective emphasized change and progress, attempting to use history to enlighten reality and propel society forward.

In his later years, despite his disappointment with the politics of the early Republic, Liang Qichao did not give up on promoting social progress. He continued writing in his later years, and his works still exert a profound influence on Chinese culture and thought. Liang Qichao passed away in Beijing in 1929 at the age of 57, leaving behind a legacy of intellectual and cultural wealth that is still remembered by later generations.

Mount Everest, located in the middle of the Himalayas, straddling the border between the Tibet Autonomous Region of China and Nepal, is the highest mountain peak in the world, with an altitude of 8,848.86 meters (according to the latest measurement data jointly released by China and Nepal in 2020). Due to its height, Mount Everest is known as the 'Roof of the World' in multiple languages.

Mount Everest is called Sagarmāthā in Nepali and its Tibetan name means 'Goddess Mother of the World.' The mountain holds great significance for mountaineering, with many famous climbers attempting or successfully summiting throughout history. The first confirmed successful summit was achieved by a New Zealand and Nepali expedition team composed of Edmund Hillary and Sherpa Tenzing Norgay on May 29, 1953.

Mount Everest is not only a challenge for extreme sports but also an important subject for geological and high-altitude ecosystem research. However, its unique climate conditions and altitude pose numerous challenges, including altitude sickness during climbing, extreme weather changes, and crevasses in glaciers.

Additionally, Mount Everest is an integral part of the local cultures of Nepal and Tibet, intertwined with many local myths and religious beliefs. Its revered status attracts tourists and mountaineers from around the world, but this also presents challenges in terms of environmental protection, such as waste management and ecological degradation.

In terms of environmental protection and sustainable tourism, the governments of China and Nepal are making various efforts to reduce the impact of human activities on Mount Everest and its surrounding environment. Despite these efforts, Mount Everest still faces environmental threats, such as glacier melting caused by global climate change.

Huangdi Neijing, fully known as the 'Yellow Emperor's Inner Canon,' consists of the 'Suwen' (Basic Questions) and the 'Lingshu' (Spiritual Pivot). It is the earliest existing theoretical work on traditional Chinese medicine, dating back to the period from the Warring States to the Han Dynasty, with a history of over two thousand years. This medical classic is widely regarded as a crucial foundational text of Chinese medicine, exerting profound influence on the subsequent development of medicine.

The 'Huangdi Neijing' is divided into two parts: the 'Suwen' mainly deals with medical theories, including the application of Yin-Yang and Five Elements in medicine, theories of pathogenesis, diagnostic methods, preventive healthcare, etc., while the 'Lingshu' focuses more on practical operations such as anatomy, physiology, acupuncture, and pathology. Together, these two parts form a complete medical system, covering the basic theories and clinical practices of traditional Chinese medicine, and they are one of the standard textbooks for later generations of Chinese medicine education.

Although traditionally attributed to the Yellow Emperor, the actual authorship of the 'Huangdi Neijing' is likely the result of contributions from many authors at different times. In ancient China, the Yellow Emperor was a cultural hero and emperor credited with many inventions and cultural achievements. Ascribing this work to him symbolizes its authoritative status in Chinese medicine.

In the history of the development of Chinese medicine, the 'Huangdi Neijing' is the first systematic summary of Chinese medical theories and practices. It not only laid the theoretical foundation of Chinese medicine but also influenced the development of East Asian medicine as a whole. The document details theories of human physiology and pathology, proposing numerous theories related to human health and disease, such as the theory of Qi and Blood, meridian theory, etc.

In modern times, despite the dominance of Western medicine, the 'Huangdi Neijing' is still widely studied and referenced in the field of traditional Chinese medicine. It is crucial for understanding and researching traditional Chinese medicine and has also attracted interest from medical and philosophical researchers worldwide, serving as a bridge for cross-cultural exchange.

The Chengde Mountain Resort, also known as the Chengde Imperial Summer Resort, is located in Chengde City, Hebei Province, China, and was the imperial palace garden of the Qing Dynasty. It was built starting from 1703 and took about 90 years to complete, primarily serving as a place for the emperor and his family to escape the summer heat and handle state affairs. The Chengde Mountain Resort not only showcases the essence of Chinese garden art but also embodies the diversity of Chinese culture.
